DOC.HEAD: NOW Fund Lists Advances, Setbacks
DOC.TEXT: The swearing in of a congresswoman, a pair of marches and the election of two pro-choice candidates for governor were among the top advances for women's rights in 1989, according to a survey released Monday by an advocacy group. A report of increasing risks to women's health because of cigarette smoking and breast cancer, a series of Supreme Court decisions on job discrimination and a presidential veto of a bill to permit use of Medicaid funds for abortions were among the most important setbacks, according to the Legal Defense and Education Fund of the National Organization for Women. Another setback was the Webster decision in the Supreme Court that, the defense fund said, ``provided states with new authority and encouragement to limit a woman's right to abortion, although technically not overturning its 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade.'' Listed under ``Terrific Trends,'' was a congressional move to provide more child care options for America's families and the expansion of the rights of gay and lesbian people living together. ``We'll look back on 1989 as a watershed year,'' said Helen Neuborne, executive director of the fund. ``Setbacks for women's reproductive and employment rights renewed the challenges to the women's movement and revitalized women's activism,'' Ms. Neuborne said. ``Public opinion polls show that the overwhelming majority of women recognize and appreciate feminism's achievements and realize that a strong movement is still needed.'' The survey listed 150 events of 1989 and singled out eight as top advances. They were: _The 27th woman, an all-time high, sworn in as a member of the House of Representatives. _A record settlement of $14 million in back pay in a case charging race and sex discrimination against employees of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. _The turnout for women's rights marches in April and November. _An injunction upheld by a federal appeals court barring protesters from blocking access to abortion clinics. _The rejection by the Florida State Legislature of anti-choice proposals and a state Supreme Court ruling striking down a parent's consent requirement for girls under 18 seeking an abortion. _The election of pro-choice gubernatorial candidates in New Jersey and Virginia. _New protections in the federal Fair Housing Act for families with children. _Rejection by the Canadian Supreme Court of an injuction won by a woman's former boyfriend that barred her from having an abortion. Setbacks listed by the fund: _A series of decisions by the Supreme Court cutting back the rights of workers to be protected from sex and race discrimination in employment _Statistics showing nearly 10 percent of AIDS cases were women and nearly two percent were children under 13. _An article in the Harvard Business Review advocating a ``mommy track'' in business. _The Webster decision. _President Bush's veto of the Medicaid bill. _The new findings on cigarette smoking and breast cancer.
